elements.content: Six cadmium(II) coordination compounds with 2-propyl-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate (H3PIDC), including two mononuclear complexes, [Cd(H2PIDC)2(H2O)2]·4H2O (1) and [Cd2(H2PIDC)4(H2O)4]·7H2O (2), two square tetranuclear complexes, [Cd4(HPIDC)4(H2O)8]·2H2O (3) and [Cd4(HPIDC)4(py)8]·10H2O (py = pyridine, 4), one one-dimensional chain polymer, [Cd2(H2PIDC)4(H2O)2]n·2nH2O (5), as well as one two-dimensional layer polymer, [Cd(H2PIDC)2] n (6), have been prepared using solvent evaporation method and hydrothermal method. The results of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses indicate that, besides the common supramolecular interactions such as hydrogen bond and π···π stacking, the hydrophobic interaction among the propyl groups in the H3PIDC ligands also contributes to the stabilities of 1–6. The study of substance transformation for 3 reveals that the coordinated H2O molecules in 3 can be well replaced by pyridine molecules, indirectly leading to the formation of 4. The results of photoluminescent measurements illustrate upon photoexcitation that 3–6 can emit fluorescence in the wavelength range of 451–473 nm in the solid state.

The results of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses indicate that, besides the common supramolecular interactions such as hydrogen bond and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking, the hydrophobic interaction among the propyl groups in the H3PIDC ligands also contributes to the stabilities of 1-6. The study of substance transformation for 3 reveals that the coordinated H2O molecules in 3 can be well replaced by pyridine molecules, indirectly leading to the formation of 4. The results of photoluminescent measurements illustrate upon photoexcitation that 3-6 can emit fluorescence in the wavelength range of 451-473 nm in the solid state.

elements.content: Presented in this article are six Cd(II) coordination compounds of 2-propyl-4,5-dicarboxylate-imidazole (H3PIDC), including two mononuclear complexes with different polymorphs, two rare square tetranuclear complexes, one one-dimensional chain polymer, as well as one two-dimensional layer polymer. It is interesting to find that, besides the common supramolecular interactions, the hydrophobic interaction among the propyl groups in the H3PIDC ligands also contributes to the stabilities of these compounds.
elements.clean_text: Presented in this article are six Cd(II) coordination compounds of 2-propyl-4,5-dicarboxylate-imidazole (H3PIDC), including two mononuclear complexes with different polymorphs, two rare square tetranuclear complexes, one one-dimensional chain polymer, as well as one two-dimensional layer polymer. It is interesting to find that, besides the common supramolecular interactions, the hydrophobic interaction among the propyl groups in the H3PIDC ligands also contributes to the stabilities of these compounds.

elements.content: Over the past several decades, the self-assembly of supramolecular architectures have received considerable attention due to their interesting functions in molecular recognition, molecular catalysis, molecular transport, and so on. In the process of assembly, the molecule structural units utilize single/cooperative noncovalent interactions as the driving forces to construct novel supramolecular architectures with reversible functional properties. These noncovalent forces usually include hydrogen bond, π···π stacking interaction, hydrophobic interaction, and so on. Among these noncovalent interactions, hydrogen bond and π···π stacking interactions, common driving forces used for the creation of supramolecular frameworks, are easily observed in supramolecular crystal structures, while hydrophobic interaction, usually existing among alkyl chains of biological macromolecules, is difficult to be observed from a crystallography perspective. The main reason may be attributed to the fact that most of the biological macromolecules have poor crystallizing behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past several decades, the self-assembly of supramolecular architectures have received considerable attention due to their interesting functions in molecular recognition, molecular catalysis, molecular transport, and so on. In the process of assembly, the molecule structural units utilize single/cooperative noncovalent interactions as the driving forces to construct novel supramolecular architectures with reversible functional properties. These noncovalent forces usually include hydrogen bond, π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interaction, hydrophobic interaction, and so on. Among these noncovalent interactions, hydrogen bond and π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions, common driving forces used for the creation of supramolecular frameworks, are easily observed in supramolecular crystal structures, while hydrophobic interaction, usually existing among alkyl chains of biological macromolecules, is difficult to be observed from a crystallography perspective. The main reason may be attributed to the fact that most of the biological macromolecules have poor crystallizing behavior.

elements.content: Imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate (H3IDC) is a well-known nitrogen heterocycle carboxylate ditopic ligand with multicoordination sites. In the past several years, we and others have used H3IDC as a building block and constructed many coordination polymers with diverse functions. Encouraged by many good examples demonstrating substituents in organic ligands can well tune the structures and subsequent functions of coordination polymers, we used 2-propyl-imidazole-4,5-dicarboxylate (H3PIDC), a derivative of H3IDC, as a building block to construct functional coordination polymers. Unfortunately, we can not get three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers with their structures similar to these based on H3IDC; instead, we obtained some examples of supramolecular architectures stabilized by diverse noncovalent interactions, of which hydrophobic interaction, limitedly observed from a crystallography perspective in biological systems, is clearly shown in these compounds. In this article, we report six H3PIDC-based supramolecular compounds, including two mononuclear complexes, [Cd(H2PIDC)2(H2O)2]·4H2O (1) and [Cd2(H2PIDC)4(H2O)4]·7H2O (2), two rare tetranuclear complexes, [Cd4(HPIDC)4(H2O)8]·2H2O (3) and [Cd4(HPIDC)4(py)8]·10H2O (py = pyridine, 4), one one-dimensional (1D) chain polymer, [Cd2(H2PIDC)4(H2O)2]n·2nH2O (5), as well as one two-dimensional (2D) layer polymer, [Cd(H2PIDC)2] n (6). Their syntheses, crystal structures, substance transformation, and luminescent properties have been investigated and discussed.

elements.content: All of the chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were determined using Elementar Vario EL elemental analyzer. The thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on NetzschTG-209 Thermogravimetry Analyzer in air atmosphere. The Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on D8 ADVANCE X-ray Diffractometer. Experimental Section

General Remarks

All of the chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were determined using Elementar Vario EL elemental analyzer. The thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on NetzschTG-209 Thermogravimetry Analyzer in air atmosphere. The Powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on D8 ADVANCE X-ray Diffractometer. Photoluminescent measurements were conducted on a RF-5301PC Spectrofluorophotometer.

elements.content: H3PIDC (0.5 mmol, 0.099 g) and 1 mmol of NaOH (0.040 g) were mixed in 10 mL of distilled water. Substance Transformation

A 0.8 g crystalline sample of 3 was immersed in 20 mL of 0.1 mol/L pyridine-1-butanol solution. Two days later, the solution was poured out, and 20 mL of fresh 0.1 mol/L pyridine-1-butanol solution was added. After being treated five times, the solid sample in light yellow color was obtained by centrifugation. The resulting solid sample (3-treated) was washed by 1-butanol and dried in air. Weight: 1.03 g.

elements.content: Single-crystal data for 1–6 were collected at 173 K on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer, with Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). All empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods, which yielded the positions of all nonhydrogen atoms. These were refined first isotropically and then anisotropically. All the hydrogen atoms of the H2PIDC–/HPIDC2– ligands and pyridine molecules were placed in calculated positions with fixed isotropic thermal parameters and included in structure factor calculations in the final stage of full-matrix least-squares refinement. The hydrogen atoms of the H2O molecules were not added. The disordered propyl groups in H2PIDC–/HPIDC2– ligands were restrained using DFIX, DELU, and SIMU instructions to make the displacement parameters more reasonable. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL system of computer programs. The crystallographic data for 1–6 are summarized in Tables and , and the selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1, .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal data for 1-6 were collected at 173 K on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD diffractometer, with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). All empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods, which yielded the positions of all nonhydrogen atoms. These were refined first isotropically and then anisotropically. All the hydrogen atoms of the H2PIDC-/HPIDC2- ligands and pyridine molecules were placed in calculated positions with fixed isotropic thermal parameters and included in structure factor calculations in the final stage of full-matrix least-squares refinement. The hydrogen atoms of the H2O molecules were not added. The disordered propyl groups in H2PIDC-/HPIDC2- ligands were restrained using DFIX, DELU, and SIMU instructions to make the displacement parameters more reasonable. All calculations were performed using the SHELXTL system of computer programs. The crystallographic data for 1-6 are summarized in Tables  and , and the selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1, .

With the same main reactants, we using diverse synthesis strategies assembled on six H3PIDC-based Cd(II) complexes with 0D/1D/2D structures. Compounds 1 and 2, synthesized at room temperature, show 0D mononuclear structures. Compounds 3 and 4, prepared at 110 °C, exhibit 0D tetranuclear architectures. Compounds 5 and 6, fabricated at 160 °C, assume 1D chain and 2D layer structures, respectively. These results indicate that the reaction temperature is a key factor that influences the polymerization degree of the product. It may be attributed to the fact that, with the increasing of the reaction temperature, the coordination ability of H2O molecule becomes weaker, and thus, the possibility of the Cd(II) coordinating with the H3PIDC ligand increases, which leads to the formation of multinuclear complexes and coordination polymers. To our knowledge, this phenomenon is well demonstrated in reported lanthanide coordination systems. Surprisingly, under the condition of high temperature, we can not successfully obtain a 3D coordination polymer, which may be ascribed to the steric hindrance of the propyl group in the H3PIDC ligand.

Results and Discussion

Preparation

With the same main reactants, we using diverse synthesis strategies assembled on six H3PIDC-based Cd(II) complexes with 0D/1D/2D structures. Compounds 1 and 2, synthesized at room temperature, show 0D mononuclear structures. Compounds 3 and 4, prepared at 110 °C, exhibit 0D tetranuclear architectures. Compounds 5 and 6, fabricated at 160 °C, assume 1D chain and 2D layer structures, respectively. These results indicate that the reaction temperature is a key factor that influences the polymerization degree of the product. It may be attributed to the fact that, with the increasing of the reaction temperature, the coordination ability of H2O molecule becomes weaker, and thus, the possibility of the Cd(II) coordinating with the H3PIDC ligand increases, which leads to the formation of multinuclear complexes and coordination polymers. To our knowledge, this phenomenon is well demonstrated in reported lanthanide coordination systems. Surprisingly, under the condition of high temperature, we can not successfully obtain a 3D coordination polymer, which may be ascribed to the steric hindrance of the propyl group in the H3PIDC ligand.

elements.content: The result of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis indicates that 1 crystallizes in P1̅ space group. As shown in Figure a, 1 is a mononuclear complex in which the central metal Cd1 is six-coordinated by two N atoms (N1, N3) and two O atoms (O1, O5) from two individual H2PIDC2– anions, as well as another two O atoms (O9, O10) from two coordinated H2O molecules, resulting in a distorted octahedral geometry. Each ligand H2PIDC2– anion, employing bidentate chelating coordination mode (Scheme , Mode I), coordinates with one Cd(II) ion. The Cd–N distances, ranging from 2.286(3) Å to 2.303(3) Å, and the Cd–O distance, ranging from 2.240(4) Å to 2.364(3) Å (Figure S1, ), are in good agreement with literature values in Cd(II) complexes. Through the coordinated interactions, one Cd(II), two H2PIDC2– anions, and two coordinated H2O molecules are assembled together to generate a complex unit (Figure a), which is further linked with another equivalent complex unit through hydrogen bond bridges (O1W: R O1···O1W = 2.839(3) Å, R O6···O1W = 2.778(4) Å. O3W: R O3···O3W = 2.910(4) Å, R N4···O3W = 2.760(3) Å; indirect hydrogen bond interactions) and hydrophobic interactions among the propyl groups to form a square supramolecular prism along the b axis (Figure b). Each prism, connecting with eight equivalent prisms along the a and c directions through direct/indirect hydrogen bond interactions, extends to a 3D supramolecular structure (Figure c,d).

elements.content: Compound 2 also crystallizes in P1̅ space group. As shown in Figure , the complex unit, the stacking mode, and the 3D structure of 2 are similar to these of 1. However, the crystal parameters of 2 are obviously different from these of 1, which may result from the different number of the lattice H2O molecules in 1 and 2. The number of H2O molecules induced polymorph variability is quite novel and interesting in crystal engineering.

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in orthorhombic crystal system, Pnma space group. As shown in Figure a, there are two crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions in each asymmetric unit. Cd1 and Cd2 exhibit similar distorted N2O4 octahedral geometries, which are completed by two N atoms and two O atoms from two individual HPIDC2– anions and another two O atoms from two terminal coordinated H2O molecules. Each HPIDC2– anion ligand, employing a bichelating bridging coordination mode (Scheme , Mode II), links two Cd(II) ions. The distance of Cd1–O1 (2.503(8) Å) is slightly longer than that of other Cd–O/Cd–N (2.236(8)–2.380(8) Å) (Table S1, ), indicating the weak contact between Cd1 and O1. Through the bridging of four HPIDC2– anions and auxiliary hydrophobic interactions, two Cd1 and two Cd2 are connected together, generating a square tetranuclear molecular unit (Figure b). Three of the propyl groups point to the center of the square, and the other one, in disorder, is outside of the square. Along the bc plane, the square tetranuclear molecular units connect with each other through intermolecular direct hydrogen bond interactions (R O1···O12 = 2.820(3) Å; R O4···O12 = 2.724(2) Å; R O6···O10 = 2.698(4) Å) to form a 2D supramolecular layer (Figure c), which further stacked with adjacent layers along the a axis through direct/indirect hydrogen bond interactions to generate a 3D supramolecular structure (Figure d).

elements.content: The result of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals 4 crystallizes in tetragonal crystal system, I41/a space group. Similar to 3, 4 is also a square tetranuclear Cd(II) complex (Figure b), in which four Cd(II) ions are bridged by four HPIDC2– anions (Scheme , Mode II). The two terminal coordination sites of each six-coordinated Cd(II) ion are completed by two pyridine molecules. This is different from 3, in which these coordination sites are occupied by H2O molecules. It is worthy noting that, after carefully searching in the latest Cambridge Structural Database (CSD), we find that, among thousands of reported complexes, these with square tetranuclear molecular units are very limited. Furthermore, the complex containing a square Cd(II) molecular unit, like in 3/4, has not been reported to date.

elements.content: It is interesting to find that there are two types of π···π stacking modes observed in 4 (Figure c), including intermolecular offset face-to-face mode between pyridine rings (π···π stacking interaction, R cg→cg = 3.798(1) Å and γ = 21.54°) and intermolecular edge-to-face mode between C16 and imidazole ring (C–H···π stacking interaction, R C→cg = 3.778(2) Å). Through these two stacking interactions, each square tetranuclear Cd(II) molecular unit, connecting with four equivalent molecular units, extends to a 2D supramolecular layer along the ab plane (Figure c). To our knowledge, π···π stacking is a common intermolecular interaction beneficial for the assembly of supramolecular compounds. However, both π···π and C–H···π stacking modes coexisting in one supramolecular compound are very limited in literatures.

Through these two stacking interactions, each square tetranuclear Cd(II) molecular unit, connecting with four equivalent molecular units, extends to a 2D supramolecular layer along the ab plane (Figure c). To our knowledge, π⋅⋅⋅π stacking is a common intermolecular interaction beneficial for the assembly of supramolecular compounds. However, both π⋅⋅⋅π and C-H⋅⋅⋅π stacking modes coexisting in one supramolecular compound are very limited in literatures.

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in P21/c space group. In the asymmetric, there are two crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions (Figure a). Cd1 coordinates with two N atoms (N1, N3) from two individual H2PIDC– anions, four O atoms (O1, O5, O16A, and O17) from three individual H2PIDC– anions, and one coordinated H2O molecule, resulting in a distorted octahedral geometry. Cd2 shows hepta-coordinated pentagonal bipyramid geometry, which is completed by two N atoms (N5, N7) from two individual H2PIDC– anions, five O atoms (O5, O6, O9, O13, and O18) from three individual H2PIDC– anions, and one coordinated H2O molecule. The H2PIDC– anions adopt three coordination modes. One is chelating mode (Scheme , Mode I), another is bichelating bridging mode (Scheme , Mode III), and the third is chelating bridging mode (Scheme , Mode IV). Through the bridging of the H2PIDC– anions, Cd1 and Cd2 are connected together to generate a 1D zigzag chain (Figure b). The adjacent chains are linked together along bc plane by direct hydrogen bond interactions (R O4···N6 = 2.802(3) Å) and indirect hydrogen interactions (O1W: R N2···O1W = 2.642(3) Å, R O1···O1W = 2.662(3) Å; R O18···O1W = 2.753(4) Å), forming a 2D supramolecular layer (Figure c). These adjacent layers are further stacked together along the a axis by direct hydrogen bond interactions (R N4···O13 = 2.948(4) Å, R O10···O17 = 2.676(4) Å), generating a 3D supramolecular structure (Figure d).

elements.content: The result of X-ray single-crystal diffraction analysis indicates 6 crystallizes in P21/n space group. As shown in Figure a, the central metal Cd1 bonds to two N atoms (N1 and N1A) and four O atoms (O1, O1A, N4A, and N4B) from four individual H2PIDC– anions, resulting in an octahedral geometry. The four O atoms locate the equatorial plane, and the two N atoms occupy the axial vertexes. Each H2PIDC– anion, employing chelating bridging coordination mode, connects two equivalent Cd(II) ions. Through the bridging of the H2PIDC– anions, the Cd(II) ions are connected together along bc plane to get a 2D 4-connected layer network (Figure b). The adjacent layers are further stacked along the a axis through hydrogen bond interaction (R N2···O2 = 2.884(2) Å) to form a 3D supramolecular structure (Figure c,d).

elements.content: It is well-known that H3IDC is a good building block used for constructing 3D functional coordination polymers. However, H3PIDC, containing the same coordination sites as H3IDC, can not bond with metal ions to get 3D coordination polymer in this work. It should be mentioned that besides these compounds in our work, the complexes recently reported by other groups also exhibit low dimensionalities. This may be ascribed to the steric hindrance of the substituent propyl group in the 2-position of imidazole ring. Interestingly, although the propyl group is not beneficial for the construction of 3D coordination polymer, it contributes to the stabilization for 1–6 through hydrophobic interactions. Especially in 1–4 and 6, several propyl groups obviously gather together, providing favorable interactions for the stabilization of these compounds. It is well-known that the hydrophobic interaction gives reasonable explanation to understand the certain structures of biomolecules and their behaviors of biological identification and selection, but in most cases, these interactions are referred by theoretical method. Although the hydrophobic interaction in biological system is slightly different from the one in crystal state, these compounds are still good examples for vivid demonstration of hydrophobic interaction from a perspective of crystallography.

Supramolecular Interactions

It is well-known that H3IDC is a good building block used for constructing 3D functional coordination polymers. However, H3PIDC, containing the same coordination sites as H3IDC, can not bond with metal ions to get 3D coordination polymer in this work. Especially in 1-4 and 6, several propyl groups obviously gather together, providing favorable interactions for the stabilization of these compounds. elements.content: X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was used to check the purity of 1–6. As shown in Figure S2, , all the peaks displayed in the measured patterns at room temperature closely match those in the simulated patterns generated from single-crystal diffraction data, which indicates single phases of them are formed.
elements.clean_text:
XRPD, Substance Transformation

X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) was used to check the purity of 1-6. As shown in Figure S2, , all the peaks displayed in the measured patterns at room temperature closely match those in the simulated patterns generated from single-crystal diffraction data, which indicates single phases of them are formed.

elements.content: Recently, structural modification has attracted much attention in material field, as it is evidenced a good approach for improving the functions of materials. Considering 3 and 4 have the similar square tetranuclear structural unit, we tried to transform 3 to 4 (see section). The XRPD patterns depicted in Figure S3, , clearly show that the 2θ values of main diffraction peaks of 3-treated are consistent with those simulated from the single-crystal diffraction data of 4, which indicates that 3 can transform to 4 after being treated by pyridine–1-butanol solution. However, the 3-treated can not return to 3 after treated by a similar way, which may be reasoned that, in this system, the coordination ability of pyridine molecule is stronger than that of H2O molecule.

However, the 3-treated can not return to 3 after treated by a similar way, which may be reasoned that, in this system, the coordination ability of pyridine molecule is stronger than that of H2O molecule.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric measurements for 1–6 were carried out from room temperature to 600 °C. As shown in Figure S4a, , the TG curve of 1 shows a weight loss of 11.5% from room temperature to 100 °C, corresponding to the removal of four lattice H2O molecules of each formula unit. When the temperature reaches 170 °C, the two coordinated H2O molecules lose (calcd 23.6%), then followed the decomposition of the rest of part 1. Compound 2 exhibits a similar TG curve to that of 1 (Figure S4a, ). From room temperature to 190 °C, the lattice H2O molecules and coordinated H2O molecules lose, and then the whole compound decomposes. Compound 3 lost two lattice H2O molecules and eight coordinated H2O molecules from room temperature to 160 °C; the weight losses found of 2.5% and 10.4% are consistent with those calculated (2.6% and 10.2%). Upon further heating, the rest of the compound fully decomposes following another two steps of weight losses (Figure S4b, ). From room temperature to 105 °C, the TG curve of 4 shows a weight loss of 8.6%, which is corresponding to the removal of 10 lattice H2O molecules (calcd 8.8%). Then, no marked weight loss is observed until 180 °C. After that temperature, the dehydrated supramolecular framework of 4 begins to decompose with the removal of the eight pyridine molecules and decomposition of the ligands (Figure S4b, ). The TG curve of 5 shows weight losses of 3.2% and 1.8% in the temperature range of 20–70 °C and 70–130 °C, respectively, corresponding to the removal of two lattice H2O molecules (calcd 3.3%) and one coordinated H2O molecule (calcd 1.7%). Upon further heating, the compound decomposes following another two steps of weight loss (Figure S4c, ). Compared with 1–5, compound 6 shows more better thermal stability (Figure S4c, ). From room temperature to 280 °C, no marked weight loss is observed. After that temperature, the compound begins to decompose following a process of continuous weight loss.

Thermal Analyses and Photoluminescent Properties

Thermogravimetric measurements for 1-6 were carried out from room temperature to 600 °C. As shown in Figure S4a, , the TG curve of 1 shows a weight loss of 11.5% from room temperature to 100 °C, corresponding to the removal of four lattice H2O molecules of each formula unit. When the temperature reaches 170 °C, the two coordinated H2O molecules lose (calcd 23.6%), then followed the decomposition of the rest of part 1. Compound 2 exhibits a similar TG curve to that of 1 (Figure S4a, ). From room temperature to 190 °C, the lattice H2O molecules and coordinated H2O molecules lose, and then the whole compound decomposes. Compound 3 lost two lattice H2O molecules and eight coordinated H2O molecules from room temperature to 160 °C; the weight losses found of 2.5% and 10.4% are consistent with those calculated (2.6% and 10.2%). Upon further heating, the rest of the compound fully decomposes following another two steps of weight losses (Figure S4b, ). From room temperature to 105 °C, the TG curve of 4 shows a weight loss of 8.6%, which is corresponding to the removal of 10 lattice H2O molecules (calcd 8.8%). Then, no marked weight loss is observed until 180 °C. After that temperature, the dehydrated supramolecular framework of 4 begins to decompose with the removal of the eight pyridine molecules and decomposition of the ligands (Figure S4b, ). The TG curve of 5 shows weight losses of 3.2% and 1.8% in the temperature range of 20-70 °C and 70-130 °C, respectively, corresponding to the removal of two lattice H2O molecules (calcd 3.3%) and one coordinated H2O molecule (calcd 1.7%). Upon further heating, the compound decomposes following another two steps of weight loss (Figure S4c, ). Compared with 1-5, compound 6 shows more better thermal stability (Figure S4c, ). From room temperature to 280 °C, no marked weight loss is observed. After that temperature, the compound begins to decompose following a process of continuous weight loss.

elements.content: The photoluminescent properties for the free ligand H3PIDC as a reference and 3–6 were investigated in the solid state. As depicted in Figure , it can be observed that 3–6 can exhibit photoluminescence upon photoexcitation at 377, 381, 398, and 392 nm, respectively. As the free ligand of H3PIDC can emit weak photoluminescence at 465 nm when excited at 340 nm, the emission peaks at 462, 461, 473, and 451 nm for 3–6, respectively, can be tentatively attributed to ligand-to-ligand charge transitions (LLCT).

elements.content: A series of Cd(II) coordination compounds based on H3PIDC have been synthesized by using solvent evaporation method and hydrothermal reaction method. The reselts of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveal that 1 and 2 are a couple of mononuclear complexes with different polymorphs, which is induced by the different number of lattice H2O molecules in 1 and 2. Compounds 3 and 4 are a couple of rare square tetranuclear complexes, in which 4 is the limited compound that contains both π···π and C–H···π stacking modes. Compound 5 is a 1D zigzag chain polymer, and 6 is a 2D 4-connected layer polymer. It is interesting to find that the hydrophobic interaction, rare observed in biological systems from a perspective of crystallography, are clearly shown in these compounds. The study of substance transformation reveals that, after being treated by pyridine–1-butanol solution, 3 can successfully transform to 4. The results of photoluminescent measurements indicate that 3–6 may be potential blue materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of Cd(II) coordination compounds based on H3PIDC have been synthesized by using solvent evaporation method and hydrothermal reaction method. The reselts of single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveal that 1 and 2 are a couple of mononuclear complexes with different polymorphs, which is induced by the different number of lattice H2O molecules in 1 and 2. Compounds 3 and 4 are a couple of rare square tetranuclear complexes, in which 4 is the limited compound that contains both π⋅⋅⋅π and C-H⋅⋅⋅π stacking modes. Compound 5 is a 1D zigzag chain polymer, and 6 is a 2D 4-connected layer polymer. It is interesting to find that the hydrophobic interaction, rare observed in biological systems from a perspective of crystallography, are clearly shown in these compounds. The study of substance transformation reveals that, after being treated by pyridine-1-butanol solution, 3 can successfully transform to 4. The results of photoluminescent measurements indicate that 3-6 may be potential blue materials.

H3PIDC (0.5 mmol, 0.099 g) and 1 mmol of NaOH (0.040 g) were mixed in 10 mL of distilled water. After stirring for 0.5 h, 0.5 mmol (0.154 g) Cd(NO3)2·4H2O in 5 mL distilled water was added drop by drop. The mixture was further stirred for another 2 h and then filtrated. The filtrate was allowed to stay at ambient temperature. After two weeks, colorless block-shaped crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were collected. Yield: 0.107 g, 35% based on Cd(NO3)2·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for C16H30N4O14Cd: C, 31.26; H, 4.92; N, 9.11. Found: C, 31.32; H, 4.88; N, 9.04. Substance Transformation

A 0.8 g crystalline sample of 3 was immersed in 20 mL of 0.1 mol/L pyridine–1-butanol solution. Two days later, the solution was poured out, and 20 mL of fresh 0.1 mol/L pyridine–1-butanol solution was added. After being treated five times, the solid sample in light yellow color was obtained by centrifugation. The resulting solid sample (3-treated) was washed by 1-butanol and dried in air. Weight: 1.03 g.

cln_elements.content:
Thermogravimetric measurements for 1–6 were carried out from room temperature to 600 °C. As shown in Figure S4a, , the TG curve of 1 shows a weight loss of 11.5% from room temperature to 100 °C, corresponding to the removal of four lattice H2O molecules of each formula unit. When the temperature reaches 170 °C, the two coordinated H2O molecules lose (calcd 23.6%), then followed the decomposition of the rest of part 1. Compound 2 exhibits a similar TG curve to that of 1 (Figure S4a, ). From room temperature to 190 °C, the lattice H2O molecules and coordinated H2O molecules lose, and then the whole compound decomposes. Compound 3 lost two lattice H2O molecules and eight coordinated H2O molecules from room temperature to 160 °C; the weight losses found of 2.5% and 10.4% are consistent with those calculated (2.6% and 10.2%). Upon further heating, the rest of the compound fully decomposes following another two steps of weight losses (Figure S4b, ). From room temperature to 105 °C, the TG curve of 4 shows a weight loss of 8.6%, which is corresponding to the removal of 10 lattice H2O molecules (calcd 8.8%). Then, no marked weight loss is observed until 180 °C. After that temperature, the dehydrated supramolecular framework of 4 begins to decompose with the removal of the eight pyridine molecules and decomposition of the ligands (Figure S4b, ). The TG curve of 5 shows weight losses of 3.2% and 1.8% in the temperature range of 20–70 °C and 70–130 °C, respectively, corresponding to the removal of two lattice H2O molecules (calcd 3.3%) and one coordinated H2O molecule (calcd 1.7%). Upon further heating, the compound decomposes following another two steps of weight loss (Figure S4c, ). Compared with 1–5, compound 6 shows more better thermal stability (Figure S4c, ). From room temperature to 280 °C, no marked weight loss is observed. After that temperature, the compound begins to decompose following a process of continuous weight loss.

The photoluminescent properties for the free ligand H3PIDC as a reference and 3–6 were investigated in the solid state. As depicted in Figure , it can be observed that 3–6 can exhibit photoluminescence upon photoexcitation at 377, 381, 398, and 392 nm, respectively. As the free ligand of H3PIDC can emit weak photoluminescence at 465 nm when excited at 340 nm, the emission peaks at 462, 461, 473, and 451 nm for 3–6, respectively, can be tentatively attributed to ligand-to-ligand charge transitions (LLCT).

Thermal Analyses and Photoluminescent Properties

Thermogravimetric measurements for 1-6 were carried out from room temperature to 600 °C. As shown in Figure S4a, , the TG curve of 1 shows a weight loss of 11.5% from room temperature to 100 °C, corresponding to the removal of four lattice H2O molecules of each formula unit. When the temperature reaches 170 °C, the two coordinated H2O molecules lose (calcd 23.6%), then followed the decomposition of the rest of part 1. Compound 2 exhibits a similar TG curve to that of 1 (Figure S4a, ). From room temperature to 190 °C, the lattice H2O molecules and coordinated H2O molecules lose, and then the whole compound decomposes. Compound 3 lost two lattice H2O molecules and eight coordinated H2O molecules from room temperature to 160 °C; the weight losses found of 2.5% and 10.4% are consistent with those calculated (2.6% and 10.2%). Upon further heating, the rest of the compound fully decomposes following another two steps of weight losses (Figure S4b, ). From room temperature to 105 °C, the TG curve of 4 shows a weight loss of 8.6%, which is corresponding to the removal of 10 lattice H2O molecules (calcd 8.8%). Then, no marked weight loss is observed until 180 °C. After that temperature, the dehydrated supramolecular framework of 4 begins to decompose with the removal of the eight pyridine molecules and decomposition of the ligands (Figure S4b, ). The TG curve of 5 shows weight losses of 3.2% and 1.8% in the temperature range of 20-70 °C and 70-130 °C, respectively, corresponding to the removal of two lattice H2O molecules (calcd 3.3%) and one coordinated H2O molecule (calcd 1.7%). Upon further heating, the compound decomposes following another two steps of weight loss (Figure S4c, ). Compared with 1-5, compound 6 shows more better thermal stability (Figure S4c, ). From room temperature to 280 °C, no marked weight loss is observed. After that temperature, the compound begins to decompose following a process of continuous weight loss.

The photoluminescent properties for the free ligand H3PIDC as a reference and 3-6 were investigated in the solid state. As depicted in Figure , it can be observed that 3-6 can exhibit photoluminescence upon photoexcitation at 377, 381, 398, and 392 nm, respectively. As the free ligand of H3PIDC can emit weak photoluminescence at 465 nm when excited at 340 nm, the emission peaks at 462, 461, 473, and 451 nm for 3-6, respectively, can be tentatively attributed to ligand-to-ligand charge transitions (LLCT).
